answers.answer: Machine learning is the field of study that gives computes the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed
answers.feedback: Correct: You could also have 'The science (and art) of programming computers so they learn from data'

answers.answer: Machine learning is about writing explicit rules and algorithms to solve specific problems
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Machine learning isn't about pre-written rules, but instead learning from data following general patterns

answers.answer: The science (and art) of programming computers so they learn from data
answers.feedback: Correct: You could also have 'Machine learning is the field of study that gives computes the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed'

answers.answer: Machine learning is about storing and retrieving vast amounts of data efficiently, like a database system.
answers.feedback: Incorrect: While ML uses data, it is about finding patterns and making predictions from said data, rather than storing/retrieving it.

question: What is the general flow of a machine learning approach to a problem?

answers.answer: Study the problem -> Write rules -> Evaluate -> Publish
answers.feedback: Incorrect: In machine learning we don't write explicit rules like in a traditional approach. We train an algorithm to learn said rules instead.

answers.answer: Study the problem -> Solve the problem -> Publish
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Although this is how ML can seem upon a quick glance, in reality 'solve the problem' is a little more involved than just that.

answers.answer: Study the problem -data-> Train model -> Evaluate -> Analyse errors -> Update data -data-> Train model -> Evaluate -> Publish
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: Collect data -> Train model -> Publish
answers.feedback: Incorrect: This skips the critical steps of ML where you evaluate the model and refine/improve it iteratively

question: Suppose you want to create and train a model that is able to determine whether a vehicle is electric, hybrid or gas (using various aspects of the car). What kind of model would you use?

answers.answer: Regression model
answers.feedback: Incorrect: regression models will predict a continuous numerical value from the new sample's input features. Our desired output here is categorical.

answers.answer: Classification model
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: Convolutional neural network
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Though this might work, its generally better to start with a simpler model before moving on to more complex models like neural networks.

answers.answer: Time-series forcasting model
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Time-series models predict future values based on past trends. This doesn't apply here, we want to categorise vehicles not predict trends.

answers.answer: This is when the input data is very poor quality (garbage in, garbage out)
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Not quite, overfitting in this case would be if your model perfectly learned this poor training data and therefore couldn't make good predictions on new samples.

answers.answer: This is where the model is too simple to make good predictions on new samples.
answers.feedback: Incorrect: This is an example of underfitting.

answers.answer: This is where you train a model that does well on your training data, but not very well on new samples.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: This is when your model is not a good fit for the dataset.
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Even if your model IS a good fit for the dataset, you can still end up overfitting if the model learns the patterns of the input data too heavily (and thusly performs poorly on new samples).

question: What is meant by a 'cost function'?

answers.answer: A function that determines the computational complexity of an algorithm
answers.feedback: Incorrect: This describes algorithmic complexity, not a cost function.

answers.answer: A metric used to assess how well the model performs on some data.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: This is a function banks use to calculate how much money to give out at an ATM.
answers.feedback: Incorrect: A cost function is not referring to expenses, but instead prediction errors in the model.

answers.answer: This is a function that calculates how much money your failed AI startup has wasted in cloud computing resources
answers.feedback: Incorrect: A cost function is not referring to expenses, but instead prediction errors in the model.

question: Generally, when training a linear regression model, what metric do we use as the cost function?

answers.answer: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: Cubic cost function
answers.feedback: Incorrect: This is commonly used in accounting.

answers.answer: Recall
answers.feedback: Incorrect: This is generally used in classification models, whilst linear regression is a regression model.

answers.answer: Gradient Descent
answers.feedback: Incorrect: This is not a cost function, but instead a method for updating a cost function.

question: What is meant by the no free lunch theorem?

answers.answer: There is no single best algorithm for predictive modelling problems; you cannot blindly take a 'good' algorithm and expect it to perform well.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: Machine learning models can achieve perfect accuracy without any training data.
answers.feedback: Incorrect: The no free lunch theorem states the opposite of this.

answers.answer: All optimisation algorithms converge to the same solution given enough time and effort
answers.feedback: Incorrect: The theorem applies to performance of models in generalised contexts, not convergence.

answers.answer: This alludes to how conferences in the machine learning space do not provide catering
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Though it can be pretty hit-or-miss, conferences usually provide catering. The theorem is about algorithmic performance, not food.

question: In ML, how can we be sure that our model truly does well in unseen scenarios?

answers.answer: Use a really large dataset
answers.feedback: Incorrect: One can still end up overfitting their models, even when using incredibly large datasets

answers.answer: Inspect predictions and use your superior intellect to ensure they 'look correct'
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Although this is a common strategy, it's generally not acceptable to do this. Human bias makes this rather unreliable.

answers.answer: Create a train and test dataset from the original (train-test split) and test the trained model on the test set
answers.feedback: Correct: One can extend this further by holding the test set till the very end, instead testing intermediate models on a validation set generated from the training dataset3

answers.answer: Use a simple model and then work your way up to more complex models
answers.feedback: Incorrect: model complexity doesn't guarantee model accuracy in unseen scenarios

question: After collecting your data and defining the problem to solve, what is best practice before choosing and training a model on said data?

answers.answer: Explore, visualise and preprocess your data
answers.feedback: Correct: This step can help you understand your data which can aid model selection. Bonus: Don't look at your test dataset to reduce your own biases.

answers.answer: Define a cost function to assess the model used
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Your cost function will likely change depending on the model you use, so this isn't a great idea.

answers.answer: Perform feature engineering
answers.feedback: Incorrect: generally you should explore your data first before deciding what features you might want to have as inputs to the model.

answers.answer: Train a complex initial model with which to compare future models
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Explore your data and try simple approaches first (perhaps not even an ML approach)

question: Which of the following is an example of an unsupervised model?

answers.answer: Logistic regression model
answers.feedback: Incorrect: This requires labelled data and so is an example of supervised learning.

answers.answer: K-means clustering
answers.feedback: Correct: This model groups unlabelled data by similarity, a classic unsupervised learning approach

answers.answer: Decision tree
answers.feedback: Incorrect: Generally you would have labelled data points to train this type of model, making it a supervised approach.

answers.answer: Diffusion model
answers.feedback: Incorrect: This is a generative model used primarily for tasks like image generation. It usually relies on labelled data points and so is supervised.
